"Due to inactive and stressful lifestyles, many people suffer from lifestyle diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, etc. Fit India Movement can encourage people to eat healthy food and maintain their physical and mental health."

"With high-quality advertising and marketing practices, malt manufacturers manipulate children to buy their food. This Fit India movement will make children think about the negative consequences of malnutrition. Therefore, this movement will encourage children to eat healthy food."

"Some parents put too much stress on their children to study. They send their children to classes after school or simply make them sit down to do their homework or forget about the importance of free time to play. This movement has the potential to change their minds and therefore they can encourage their children to go out and play."

"This movement has the potential to make more people embrace traditional forms of Indian martial arts such as Kathi Samu, Musti Yudha, etc., and traditional dance forms and also healthy Indian snacks. And as a by-product, it can lead to job creation."
"The motivation to maintain physical fitness should begin at an early age. But in India, many schools lack playgrounds. The lack of playgrounds may encourage children to adopt inactive lifestyles."

"Fit India Movement may not reach people living below the poverty line. To maintain a healthy lifestyle, physical activity and nutritious foods are necessary. But in India, many people still suffer from malnutrition and some lack access to safe drinking water. Thus, without addressing the issue of poverty and lack of access to affordable nutritious food, part of the Indian population will not be able to benefit from this movement."

"Some people are already focusing on physical fitness. We can see this with the growing number of fitness startups. But it is a small proportion of people. In general, many people want to maintain an active lifestyle, but all they need is some encouragement. So this movement constantly reminds people to focus on fitness goals, just as Swachh Bharat reminds us of the importance of keeping our environment clean."

"Since the invention of machines, the value of workers has declined. They are made to work to support machines. Consequently, work revolves around machines and not humans. Workers are obliged to work continuously with the machine."
"People are now trolling and cyberbullying. Hiding behind the aircraft gives them the courage to harass other people, which they cannot do face to face. It is the deterioration of moral values."

"Some companies are building strategies to use their applications for longer, to keep us dependent on their applications and devices so that they can show us ads. And they can also use our data to manipulate our decisions for their benefit. These strategies turn people into simple targets."

"Industrialization has increased working hours. Workers are in inhumane conditions. Humans cannot work and concentrate continuously like machines. Fast forward to today, we have technological devices to check how many hours we actually work. Some companies want to be connected 24 hours a day through emails and messages. This makes people feel less human."

"Our decision-making skills are also affected, because we are now asking search engines to know what is best. We rely on the Internet knowledge base even in the office to complete the work at hand. This affects cognitive skills (thinking, reading, learning, remembering and reasoning), which is an essential human quality."

"Many face-to-face communications are also being replaced by virtual interactions. Many people now live in virtual homes, which is the smartphone. As the need to talk to each other diminishes, the ability to communicate with each other, which is a fundamental quality of living beings, diminishes."

"We are increasingly dependent on technological devices to guide us. For example, we keep reminders on smartphones and google the questions for answers. We underestimate activities that require intelligence to technology. Thinking, remembering and analyzing are essential qualities of human beings. Too much reliance on technology makes us less human."

"Through technology, people maintain and improve their relationships with their friends, family and loved ones. Many people also connect with each other to help the needy and to inspire each other. So now we have better tools to build human connections."

Technology allows us to work from home. This facility helps employers better understand employees. Many companies are now adding elements to the work culture with the help of technology to make employees feel important.

"This bill conferred exclusive powers on the National Investigation Agency (NIA). The NIA may place any person in police custody under the AFS without the prior authorization of the state government. It is against federalism, which is guaranteed by India's constitution."

"Labelling organizations as terrorist organizations and individuals as terrorists are quite different. If a person is designated as a terrorist, he or she will face social exclusion and deprivation of livelihood, even if he or she has proved otherwise. The consequences will be irreversible. For example, in 2016 alone, 67% of cases resulted in acquittal, which means they are probably innocent."

"If someone is segregated under the AHU, the burden of proving his or her innocence falls on them. This new amendment allows the government to seize its assets. So how are they going to pay the legal costs of proving their innocence if they are falsely accused?'

"It will give more police powers to the central government. The possibility of designating individuals as terrorists could be misused. For example, recently several civilian activists have been called urban Naxals. If someone opposes the government, he or she will be vulnerable to being described as a terrorist. Because this amendment has made it easier to describe anyone as a terrorist.'

"The terrorism of lone wolves is increasingly threatened. Solitary wolf terrorists have no association with terrorist organizations, but they carry out terrorist attacks alone. This new amendment to the UAPA is likely to curb wolf terrorism on its own."

"In order to prevent human rights violations, a four-step review is added. India has not begun to designate individuals as terrorists. The United States, the European Union and China also have this provision.'

“Until now, only organizations were designated as terrorist organizations, but not individuals. The shortcoming is that the individuals of the proscribed organizations form new organizations and carry out terrorist activities. This draft amendment to the Prevention of Illegal Activities Act allows the Government to designate individuals as terrorists, thereby preventing terrorist attacks."
There is a need to take strong action against terrorism in the context of the growing threats from terrorists. There is therefore a need to strengthen AHS.

"At present, India does not have a well-developed data security infrastructure. On the other hand, developed countries already had an effective infrastructure. Thus, rushing to locate the data may not be a wise step. Because in the absence of an effective infrastructure, data is susceptible to cyber attacks. And the risk here is serious because it is financial data. But as legislation is passed, it is very difficult to develop efficient infrastructure at a faster pace."

"Data storage in India entails higher operational costs for payment system operators. Because in other countries they have cheaper alternatives. And also for cross-border transactions, they have to store data in two places, which increases costs. It is likely that these additional costs can be passed on to consumers."

"Data location laws lead to the establishment of several data centres locally. This will create many jobs and will greatly help the country's economy. It will also stimulate innovation on the ground, leading to low-cost solutions."

"While investigating crimes, it will be necessary to access payment data. If the data are stored abroad, it is very difficult to obtain permission from that country to access the data. This leads to delays in the resolution of crimes. If the data are stored here in our country, this problem will be avoided."

"India is a major consumer market for many foreign companies. Thus, India and other developing countries realize the economic value of data and the importance of data location. With the localization of the data, national enterprises and the country's economy will benefit. And we can also ensure data security."

"The data are considered a 'new form of wealth'. In general, companies use the data to understand consumer demands and also to influence consumer behaviour. New products can be developed by analyzing the data to meet consumer needs. The data are therefore of economic value. In general, developed countries benefit from this opportunity through their well-developed infrastructure.”

"We are in a globalized world. At present, the world operates on the free movement of people, goods, services and data. Data location laws appear to be part of protectionist policies, which poses a threat to the free flow of data."

"The United States is against data location laws. Recently at the G20 summit, Donald Trump, the President of the United States, spoke out against locating the data. Its position is natural because it increases the operating costs of American companies. Bilateral relations between India and the United States are important for both countries because we are related to the export and import of computer services, professionals and goods, etc. Therefore, imposing laws to locate data without threatening Indo-American relations is another challenge."
We can ensure the confidentiality of the data by locating the data.
The location of the data can lead to government surveillance of its citizens.
"The location of data is important for data sovereignty, which means that citizens' data should be held by their respective governments and not by other countries."

The Act is very clear that RTI does not deal solely with government agencies. It also applies to non-governmental organizations that are substantially funded and controlled by the Government. There are many subsidies (including tax exemptions) that benefit political parties and are therefore substantially funded by the Government.
"Political parties are independent bodies, they are not accountable to the public. They have not been established by the Constitution or by a law of Parliament."

"The ITR Act stipulates that wherever there is a public interest, these bodies must be transparent and fall within the scope of the Act. There are now a number of private organizations, both partially and fully funded; schools, hospitals, etc. who are under the Access to Information Act and not just government organizations."
The Income Tax Act and the Electoral Commission have adequate provisions that allow people to have the information they want.

"The ITR Act contains provisions under section 8 that refer to the concept of competitive interest. Certain exemptions are provided where it can be demonstrated that the disclosure of information may adversely affect the competitive advantage of the party. This is not only a problem with political parties, but also with a large number of governmental and private bodies."

"Political financing is believed to be the source of corruption. Citizens have the right to know where political parties collect these funds, how they spend them and on the basis of their decisions. Crony's capitalism will be severely curtailed if political parties are subject to the RTI Act."

"Under the IT Act, political parties do not need to disclose donations that are less than INR 20,000. An informal study conducted in 2010 on 6 key political parties shows that they raised Rs 700 crore. 95 per cent of the amount was increased by amounts below Rs 20,000. It is highly likely that political parties will use this shortcoming to their advantage."
"Political parties declare certain promises in their manifestos. After being elected, citizens have the right to know why the promises made by political parties have not been honoured."

"Political parties are at the heart of the functioning of democracy. Political parties form the government. Government policies are then governed by party ideology. Thus, it becomes essential that political parties be subject to the AIT."

"If political parties fall under the RTI, this will affect their proper internal functioning. Rivals may use RTI to malign itself. Furthermore, since political parties are not directly linked to the public, an IPR would be invalid."

"Overall, Indians see educational institutions as employment machines, we expect to go into unemployment and find a job. We do not realize that we will have to improve our skills in order to become employable. That is why more than 80% of engineers are unemployed and the figures are even worse for non-engineers."

"While we have established national institutes over the past 40 years, we have not invested in maintaining their standards. Funds are needed for quality education. Even the best Indian institutes lack infrastructure, laboratories, resources, etc. And even what is available is just for students to pass the exam and remain inactive the rest of the time."
"Today, no problem has a single solution and no new technology is linked to a single discipline. We need multiple contributions from many disciplines and our institutes have failed to do so."

"Indian students perform brilliantly when they travel to different countries in the field of research. This means that we do not lack talent, we lack infrastructure and a healthy environment for our living minds."

"We have not paid our teachers on the scale of what their counterparts earn in other countries. As a result, people are reluctant to teach as a career. Nor have we succeeded in attracting foreign faculties to our institutes."

"It takes time to achieve excellence in anything. With their degrees, students gain so much knowledge in the relevant field. This makes it easier for employers to train these students in industrial requirements."
Any skill can be learned and mastered even if we don't have a degree in this area. And programming is no exception.

"Even if someone has a degree in IT, they have to learn so much to get into IT work, because there is a gap between industry standards and the skills that are taught in engineering colleges. Furthermore, because technology is constantly evolving, even if one has prepared for industrial standards in one's diploma, one must constantly learn new technologies in order to remain relevant in the labour market. Thus, since the learning curve will be the same for IT students, students in non-IT environments can also learn these things and can enter IT jobs."

"The number of jobs in information technology is growing at a rapid pace due to the technological revolution. As a result, there will be more jobs in information technology. And if recruiters are very strict on the degree, they may lack a large pool of talent, who are from a non-IT past."

"Now we have so many online course platforms through which we can learn almost any expert skill. We can also obtain certificates if we pass the tests. So, as Tim Cook said, a four-year degree seems old and traditional."

"In many engineering schools in India, we can easily pass the subjects even if they do not have much knowledge in these subjects. This is why many companies are unable to find suitable talent, even though there are so many qualified graduates. Therefore, the desire to become an expert in the field is more important than a degree."
"If a student of non-IT origin has chosen to start a career in computer science, his efforts to graduate will be in vain."
"Although new programming languages replace older ones, the basic concepts are the same for almost all programming languages. Thus, a graduate in coding will have an advantage over a non-IT student."

"People change careers even after working in a field for several years because our interests change. So when someone can do it with so much personal responsibility, it's much easier for young people to learn a new skill."
"Flexible pay certainly increases employee productivity. High performers feel well paid and rewarded for their efforts, while low performers also feel motivated to improve."

"In variable pay plans, employees feel satisfied and motivated by their work. They feel that they are an integral part of the organization, that they recognize them as part of its growth, and that they value their efforts."

"Variable pay helps retain valuable employees. This helps to retain good talent for long periods of time and thus reduces expenditures on hiring new talent. This ensures the stability of the organization."

" It has been found that it is difficult to keep employees on lay-offs when they are subject to variable remuneration schemes. Workers who receive commissions do well when things are good, but they do badly when things are bad. In times of business slowdown, even the best sellers may find it difficult to make enough sales to earn a decent living. If the market is slow and the contracted workers cannot earn enough, they can look for other employment opportunities. In times of weakness, fixed wages can be more effective in preventing employees from leaving for other opportunities."

"Variable remuneration can lead to unhealthy competition among employees. They are becoming less willing to help each other. Teamwork can be negatively affected. In the long run, co-worker relationships can become bitter. Whereas, in fixed-rate systems, employees are able to maintain cordial relations in the office."

"Most of the time, sales jobs have a variable component. This could have a negative impact on the employee's attitude towards clients. They can force customers irrationally just to make profits for themselves. They could overestimate the price for customers just to make more profit. Whereas a fixed-wage employee would maintain healthy and positive relationships with clients, which would allow him to find the right balance in his approach."

"The enormous data we generate every day is analyzed and fed into our devices through algorithms that we end up giving gadgets more and more control over our lives. We may feel that we receive all these services free of charge, but they come at the cost of our precious time and attention."

"With all the data and algorithms, our applications and gadgets, without our conscious knowledge, make decisions for us. Decision-making is (was) one of the qualities that made humans different from others."

"After a daily 10 a.m. shift from Monday to Friday, most of us prefer to stay at home during the holidays. We surround ourselves with laptops, TVs and mobiles and we use them in cycles for Netflix, sports, social networks, etc. (thinking we're relaxing) rather than going out. We prefer and are more comfortable with online conversation instead of talking to people for real. There are fewer meaningful relationships today because of all of the above factors. We have begun to prefer isolation."

"Nuclear technology is a very effective alternative to non-renewable energy resources. But we have always chosen to move forward with more and more types of nuclear warheads. The same is true of almost all other inventions. Similarly, although in the beginning the IA promised us better lives, because of the IA, we began to lose our basic human qualities."
"We have begun to lose our basic human habits and instincts, and we are in fact governed by machines and applications."

"As Yuval Noah Harari says, what we need now is morality and spirituality. Morality is about reducing suffering in the world. And spirituality is questioning and seeking answers. Religions just give us answers and no scope for questions."

"Religion has served its purpose of uniting people, establishing structures in society and developing trust and cooperation. But in the 21st century, we are growing towards objective realities, and religion is an inter-subjective reality and now all it does is create differences in the world, wash people's brains, develop animosity for other beliefs, and provide rituals that are just shortcuts to becoming a good person. (A Muslim may pray 5 times a day; a Hindu may pray every day for hours in temples; a Christian may go to church every day, but still be involved in immoral activities)."

"In the past, everything unknown dealt with religious beliefs. But now science and technology have taken over. We know the reasons for drought, earthquakes, windstorms, etc. These are scientific phenomena, not the wrath of the gods."

"Due to their technological nature, new banks do not need physical bank branches, which helps them to save on overhead costs (the cost of running the business). As a result, new banks are able to offer customers lower fees and higher interest rates on control and savings accounts."

"People don't trust new banks as much because they don't have a physical presence, which makes them a risk to clients in the event of problems or challenges. In-person customer service may seem more trustworthy to customers."

Technological literacy is still very low in India. Traditional banks can meet the banking requirements of less technologically savvy customers or people in rural areas of the country who prefer to interact face-to-face with the manager.
"Commercial banks contribute to the creation of credit, which leads to an increase in production, employment and consumer expenditure, which contributes to the growth of the economy."
"As new banks are fully digital, they operate 24 hours a day and their services are available at all times. They are easily accessible from anywhere via a smartphone."

"Fintech companies can open specialized new banks that target a specific type of customer. For example, LXME aims to become India's first Neo Bank for Women, offering product solutions that meet women's specific financial needs and emotional preferences."
"5G in the banking sector will provide the necessary financial inclusion for rural and remote populations in India, for whom access to a physical bank is not possible."

"The low latency of 5G will allow for the inclusion of education in remote areas of India, where children will have access to good quality education at home without any network gap between them and their preferred guardian. In addition, 5G will enable the use of new technologies such as RA and VR for more immersive learning in schools and colleges."

"5G will dramatically increase the number of networks that can be connected, handling up to a trillion Internet object terminals, allowing machines and people in a factory to communicate seamlessly, making the business more efficient and reducing the possibility of error."

"The Government will be able to improve its governance and support its India Digital Initiative, which is aimed at ensuring that government services are made available to citizens electronically, thereby enabling the country to build digital capacity in the area of technology."
"Hydrogen is flammable and can cause fires or explosions. Therefore, it is not yet completely certain."
"If hydrogen production uses fossil fuels, it can be counterproductive. It is therefore important to use renewable energy to produce hydrogen."

"Hydrogen-cell vehicles do not emit greenhouse gases. This helps to combat climate change. With many countries opting for energy transition, clean hydrogen vehicles and other alternative fuel vehicles can pave the way for sustainable transport. Furthermore, since these vehicles do not emit greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide, they can greatly reduce air pollution."
"The prices of fossil fuels are constantly rising. Therefore, if more hydrogen vehicles enter the market, the price of fossil fuels could decrease."
"Hydrogen vehicles are much quieter than fossil fuel vehicles. In this way, they can also reduce noise pollution."
"If hydrogen escapes into the air, it can increase global warming."

"During the pandemic, social media helped people maintain their social lives.Social media allowed them to stay in touch with friends and loved ones all the time. We can easily know what is going on in their lives. It allowed us to communicate with many people at the same time by sharing messages."

"Thanks to social media, we now have the opportunity to connect with many people, even if they don't live in our region. Before social media, we could interact with people in our community or where we go."

"By following friends on social networks and not communicating with them in private, we can only know what they post on their accounts. We may not know much about what actually happens in their lives. This means that we will have no meaningful connection with friends. The ease of contacting people online made us prefer to meet them outside."

"Some people now have social anxiety because they don't have enough face-to-face interactions. When we avoid talking to people for a long time, we automatically develop a fear of participating in small speeches."
The trolling of social media is a major threat. It affects the self-esteem of many people and also prevents them from forming social bonds.

"In the book 'iGen', it was mentioned that in the next decade we might see more young people who know just the right emoji for a situation — but not the right facial expression. This can become true if we prefer virtual life to real life."

"Through close communities or micro-communities based on shared interests in social media as well as private messages, social media has given us the opportunity to make real connections with people we can truly connect with."
"The NEET standardizes the entry criteria for medical education across the country. Since a high mark is required to enter government medical colleges, the examination ensures meritocracy."

"But every year, less than 20% of students pass the exam. As a result, it is evident that the quality of medical education in other countries where Indian students study is not commensurate with the quality of medical education in India. It is therefore very important to take steps to provide affordable and high quality medical education in India."

"As the examination requires further study, the coaching centres take advantage of the situation and charge lakhs of rupees for coaching for the NEET examination. Therefore, because of this, students who cannot afford coaching are at a disadvantage."

"Students work hard to score well in class 12 exams, but all this hard work is not recognized. And only the NEET score is considered for entry into medical college, which is very unfair. In addition, the NEET examination is primarily based on the CBSE curriculum. Therefore, the students of the Council of State must study additional things in order to obtain a good mark on the examination."

"A high NEET score is required for admission to government medical colleges in India. It costs about Rs. 1.25 crore to study in private medical colleges in India. For example, many students are forced to go to other countries such as China, Ukraine, Russia, the Philippines, etc. continue medical studies. In these countries, medical education costs around Rs.35 lakhs. In addition, they allow students with low NEET scores but above the thresholds."

Some people clear the moon to pursue their passion when the earnings of their passion can not replace the salary of their main job. Many entrepreneurs take this route and leave their jobs once they have earned enough from their new businesses.
"According to a study published by the Academy of Management Journal in 2021, moonlight can provide a sense of control and motivation, which can improve employee productivity."

"The sudden layoffs of several companies, especially during the pandemic, caused fear among many employees. And so several people took parallel concerts or a second job as a safety net in case they were fired."

Moonlight can help increase loss of life. Some people want to acquire new skills outside of what they are working on in their main job. This can help them develop their expertise in their field. Some may get bored with monotonous jobs and therefore take a second job to learn new skills and thus make their days exciting.
Companies are concerned about sensitive information and data theft and the possibility of sharing it with rival companies.

Some managers are concerned that moonlit employees may not be productive in their core work due to fatigue and increased stress. There are also concerns about working for other companies during the office hours of my main job.

"In general, companies offer several benefits to employees, such as contingency funds, health insurance, etc. Thus, they feel it is unfair for their employees to concentrate their energy and time on a second job, which does not provide any of these benefits."

An economy without money saves so much money for governments because printing and sending money to the banks requires money and human resources. The need to purchase or lease land for ATMs will also be eliminated. International payments will also be easier because there is no need to exchange currencies.
Cashless transactions leave digital fingerprints of financial transactions. They can be used to trace illegal activities.
COVID Pandemic increased the number of cashless transactions. They can prevent the spread of contagious diseases.

"Non-cash transactions are recorded by banks. In this way, the data will reveal people's critical data about where they spend their money. The government has easy access to anyone's data. This may result in mass surveillance programs. This is contrary to the right to privacy. Money gives us anonymity."
An economy without money will increase the number of cybercrimes.
Technical problems in the banking sector can stop access to our money. This can interfere with our daily lives.

"Refugees are forcibly displaced. They flee their countries for a number of reasons such as violence, human rights violations, war, persecution of minorities, etc. They often face threats to their lives in their countries of origin. They leave their homes and everything else in search of a safer place to live."

"Currently, many countries refuse refugees to declare that they pose a threat to the economy or security. Only a few countries, including Lebanon, Jordan, Turkey and Liberia, accept most refugees. Some host countries forcibly send refugees to their countries of origin, declaring that the situation in their countries of origin is secure. Many of the refugees who have been sent in this way have suffered brutal violence and some people have even disappeared."

All countries should share responsibility for refugees. The resettlement of refugees must take place without delay. They should be offered developmental courses and employment opportunities to help them lead a dignified life.

"A weak global response aggravates the refugee situation. The international community should help to rebuild the war-torn countries from which the refugees came, so that safe and dignified returns were possible for the refugees. Refugees should not be forcibly returned to their countries of origin."
"Many developed countries spend so much money to protect their borders, but do not spend money to protect the lives of refugees. Additional funds are needed to protect refugees."
